title: 105_hr2833
content: The Act is titled the "MacBride Principles of Economic Justice Act of 1997" and includes amendments to the Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to prioritize using United States contributions to increase employment opportunities in communities with high unemployment rates in Northern Ireland and benefit individuals in those communities. The United States' contributions under the Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 should be directed towards individuals or entities in Northern Ireland that follow principles of economic justice. Additional requirements and certifications are also amended. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to direct contributions to individuals and entities in Northern Ireland following principles of economic justice. Additional requirements for annual reports are also updated. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to include requirements for funds and definitions related to economic justice principles. The Act now prohibits quotas, reverse discrimination, or mandates for their use. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to include economic justice principles such as increasing representation of underrepresented religious groups in the workforce, providing security for minority employees, banning provocative emblems, and advertising job openings publicly. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to include provisions for economic justice, such as increasing representation of underrepresented religious groups in the workforce, ensuring job security for minority employees, abolishing discriminatory practices, developing training programs for minority employees, and implementing procedures for recruiting and advancing minority employees. The Anglo-Irish Agreement Support Act of 1986 is amended to include provisions for economic justice, such as appointing a senior management staff member to oversee employment efforts and implementing specified principles within a reasonable timeframe. The amendments will take effect 180 days after the enactment of this Act.
